summary: Caleb Smith (Domhnall Gleeson) a programmer at a huge Internet company, wins a contest that enables him to spend a week at the private estate of Nathan Bateman (Oscar Isaac), his firm's brilliant CEO. When he arrives, Caleb learns that he has been chosen to be the human component in a Turing test to determine the capabilities and consciousness of Ava (Alicia Vikander), a beautiful robot. However, it soon becomes evident that Ava is far more self-aware and deceptive than either man imagined.

reviews.content:
As a lover of science fiction, I am always on the lookout for films that push the boundaries of the genre and challenge my perception of the future. Ex Machina, directed by Alex Garland, is a true gem that does exactly that. This visually stunning and intellectually provocative film is a masterclass in storytelling, boasting a thought-provoking plot, brilliant performances, and breathtaking visuals that left me mesmerized from start to finish.

One of the standout elements of Ex Machina is its captivating and thought-provoking plot. The story follows Caleb (played by Domhnall Gleeson), a young programmer who wins a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to interact with an advanced humanoid AI named Ava (played by Alicia Vikander) created by the enigmatic and reclusive genius, Nathan (played by Oscar Isaac). As Caleb delves deeper into his interactions with Ava, he becomes entangled in a web of secrecy and deception, questioning the true nature of Ava's consciousness and Nathan's motives. The film raises profound questions about the ethics of artificial intelligence, the boundaries of humanity, and the consequences of playing god with technology. The script is meticulously crafted, filled with tension, and keeps you on the edge of your seat until the very end.

The performances in Ex Machina are simply outstanding. Alicia Vikander's portrayal of Ava is breathtaking. She effortlessly balances innocence and allure, creating a character that is both mesmerizing and unnerving. Domhnall Gleeson brings empathy and vulnerability to his role as Caleb, and Oscar Isaac is magnetic as the eccentric and enigmatic Nathan. The chemistry between the three actors is palpable, driving the tension and dynamics of the film to new heights. Each performance is nuanced, complex, and adds layers of depth to the story, making it a truly immersive experience.

Visually, Ex Machina is a feast for the eyes. The film features stunning cinematography that beautifully captures the sleek and minimalist setting of Nathan's isolated compound. The juxtaposition of the cold, sterile environment with the warm, lifelike presence of Ava creates a sense of unease and fascination. The visual effects used to bring Ava to life are seamless and awe-inspiring, making her feel like a truly authentic AI entity. The production design and special effects are top-notch, creating a fully realized and immersive world that draws you in from the very first frame.

In addition to its visual and narrative prowess, Ex Machina also excels in its thought-provoking themes and intellectual depth. The film poses deep philosophical questions about the nature of consciousness, the morality of creating sentient beings, and the implications of AI on humanity. It delves into the complexities of human emotions, the power dynamics between humans and machines, and the blurred lines between reality and illusion. Ex Machina is a film that lingers in your mind long after the credits roll, sparking conversations and debates about the ethical implications of artificial intelligence in our society.

Ex Machina is a masterpiece of modern science fiction. With its riveting plot, stellar performances, breathtaking visuals, and profound themes, it is a thought-provoking and intellectually stimulating film that challenges our perceptions of the future and the ethical implications of technology. It is a must-watch for any science fiction aficionado or anyone who appreciates intellectually engaging cinema. Ex Machina is a compelling, visually stunning, and intellectually rich cinematic experience that will leave you captivated and pondering its questions long after the credits roll.
Intelligent, claustrophobic and thoughtfull movie about the gaining of independence of AI with a modern veneer of the Frankenstein theme.

Alex Garland's directorial debut is a stylish sci-fi flick that shows just what happens when men try to play God. The ‘28 Days Later' writer brings Domhall Gleeson, Oscar Isaac and Alicia Vikander together in this high-tech feature that plays like a loose adaptation of ‘The Tempest'. Spanning over 108-minutes, ‘Ex Machina' marks A24's first Academy Award for Visual Effects, winning over films like ‘Mad Max: Fury Road' and ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens', the latter happened to feature both Isaac and Gleeson also.

‘Mother!' star Domhall Gleeson gives a strong performance, starring as ingenuous programmer Caleb Smith. When Caleb is chosen to stay with Nathan Bateman (a narcissistic, reclusive CEO brought to life by a notable performance from Oscar Isaac), he soon discovers the purpose of his stay is to test a ground-breaking new AI known as ‘Ava'. Ava is played by ‘Tomb Raider' star Alicia Vikander, who's performance as the synthetic humanoid is both chilling and inquisitive. However, as Ava becomes increasingly conscious and her bond with Caleb grows, her path to freedom is progressively fuelled by deception and manipulation, leading to fatal consequences.

‘Ex Machina' explores the divide between technology and man, Garland shows viewers that when powerful men try to play God, more often than not, it ends in chaos, as shown in films like ‘I, Robot' and ‘Avengers: Age of Ultron'. Despite its futuristic aesthetic, the film appears to draw influences from past theatrics like Shakespeare's ‘The Tempest' as well as Greek Tragedy theatre, as shown by the various masks placed along the wall in Nathan's home. Even the film's title draws from historic theatre, ‘Ex Machina' being derived from the Latin phrase ‘Deus ex Machina' which means ‘a god from the machine'. The film also goes down the path of exploring the fact that artificial intelligence can be seen as evolution, in response to Caleb asking about why Nathan created Ava he responds "I don't see Ava as a decision, just an evolution". This haunting realisation shows how in the future humans could be seen as obsolete as AI becomes more and more developed and aware

The present day setting of ‘Ex Machina' allows Garland to show viewers just how close we could be to something like Ava existing, and the possible ensuing disaster coming to fruition. Rob Hardy's sleek cinematography and Mark Digby's contemporary production design, provides the film with ultra-modern visuals that reflect the technology-focused plot. Considering the film only had a $15 million budget, ‘Ex Machina's visuals effects are spectacular, and the fact it beat out its competitors, all of which had budgets of over $100 million,, makes it that much more impressive. The film also brings up the issue that whatever you search online is watched, recorded and stored. In ‘Ex Machina's case, the trillions of searches help Nathan to develop Ava and create her persona.

Alex Garland brings viewers a polished sci-fi drama that features strong performances from all three main characters, sleek set design and a superb script courtesy of Garland himself. ‘Ex Machina' is a triumphant first outing in the director's chair for Garland, who's film leaves you on the edge of your seat by the time the credits roll.
Plenty of unexpected twist in turns. Definitely worth a watch!
Excellent, smart and entertaining
This movie was not what I expected, but it was so good. Highly recommend.
Certainly an interesting movie with an intriguing message, but dull and slow at times as well.
The premise is fascinating. And so is the film. It also had not one, but two twists. Both worked well enough. One worked more than well enough.

Firstly, what surprises me most about this piece of art is the roles that actor lead, the film only shows four characters, notwithstanding this fact this decision could not be more correct, since they are so few, the director is free to deepen on their lives and beliefs, and for surprise of anyone, these characters are so realistic that they could be actual people. Only a minority of movies can take pride in this aspect.

Secondly, it is no wonder why this movie has got the Oscar for best special effects, the effects applied on this movie are on point with the situation that the spectator lives, and they are so authentic that they do not seem artificial at all. The part that really exploits this fact is when Ava interacts just like a real person.

Alternatively, I could understand why many consider this film too audacious and not realistic, it shows such a distant alternative world that you could just lock your mind and not think outside the box. However, It is my firm belief that taking this approach, makes the film more interesting and intriguing.

Despite the negative aspects mentioned, Ex-Machina still is a great film that contextualize how the  proper future could be. Who knows, an android like Ava could soon be created.

It's crazy how this movie greatly depicted how we are in real life, maybe there's someone above or out there that has programmed us to do what we do; truly feels like a Truman show but more like Truman being an AI and with some dark ambiance.

Whether as a novelist, a screenwriter or a director, Alex Garland is generally willing to tackle challenging and interesting themes.  Such is the case with Ex Machina, Garland's take on artificial intelligence and the potential dangers it presents.  When tech company owner Nathan (Oscar Isaac) invites his employee Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson) to visit his remote research facility, things take an unexpected turn when Caleb is introduced to Ava (Alicia Vikander), a life-like piece of A.I. that may be more complex than anyone understands.  Ex Machina is thought-provoking and relentlessly entertaining, featuring great performances from the cast (especially Vikander's understated but effective portrayal of Ava), great sets and locations, and some really smart writing courtesy of Garland.  Even non-science fiction fans will find something to like here – it's that good.
One of the greatest films of all time.

this movie had good pacing and nice dialogue between every character. In some conversation, its bring sarcasm to society and industry. Although it didn't have a good ending as I expected, it has a deep meaning behind it.

Boring, dull, slow. I had so many breaks throughout the movie because I could not stand its pace. Fewer characters, mostly dark scenes and lethargic conversations. I do not understand what is to like about this movie. The message is strong though (this is the only reason for my score), but the plot is lifeless, and the end of the movie leaves you with a feeling of "What The F". Caleb was such a genuine and kind person just to end up abandoned, jailed, starving. Ava was still a machine, so I never felt any empathy for her, regardless of this being the intention of the director.

Terrific performances by each of the three stars. The weird vibes certain characters give off make you want to learn more and see how their research goes. All of that and a well done final act makes this a movie I'd recommend. You will surely be left laying in bed thinking about the ending.

A few years back I googled up best sci-fi since 2012. Having been very ill for several years — I needed to play catch-up with movies I had missed. So during my recovery, I watched many, many movies I never knew existed. Ex Machina was one of them. This is a thinking person's type of sci-fi, very brainy stuff but still has the basic formula of smug scientist finally builds a robot smarter and more powerful than he expected. I won't go in to detail but do watch this somewhat disturbing movie that has superb special FX.
I'm glad I watched this movie, years later, for a second time. Now I get it! There are no  heroes or villains. We are simply invited to watch evolution as it unfolds.

Ex Machina is an excellent and thoughtful work. To start, though the film only really contains a small handful of actors, the work they do is truely superb. The VFX is also excellent. The plot of the film is well crafted and really challenges the viewer intellectually, it is also accentuated by a great score. Most interesting though is that the film is not only about a Turing test, it is one in a way. The one weak point in my opinion is the ending, it just seems to be lacking a little of the polish apparent everywhere else in the film.
93/100

Very thought-proving and profound film from debutant Alex Garland. I thoroughly enjoyed the build-up and slow-burn of the story. Although, I was able to guess a couple of twists, it caught me by surprise a lot. Performances all across the board were excellent. If you like sci-fi, this movie should definitely be on your watchlist. Especially, computer science students like me.

Great movie - different than most and unpredictable. 
I like that.

Cerebral to the extent that significant parts of the film are devoted to lofty philosophical discussions, this works so well with its nagging unease and technical excellence. The performances are all superb - I especially liked Oscar Isaac as the (would-be?) alpha male tech genius, manipulating everybody and everything to serve his own agenda, the passive aggressive bulky to whom all beings are means to an end. I've met many tech and non tech types like him. The direction, script, production design, score and much more all work brilliantly; and the disciplined running time is a refreshing strength. Its only real weakness for me was a key reveal about 30 minutes from the end was easily guessed ahead - but even that may have been deliberate.

Ex Machina forces you to take one side: the brilliant though ambiguous computer scientist or the dumb test case who's falling in love with a machine. And just when you think you got it right, you find out you didn't.

Disfruté mucho ver esta película por cómo la Trama te envuelve en cómo es posible que puede existir una inteligencia artificial tan avanzada estas actuaciones me encantaron y pienso que es muy buena película

I liked this movie for one reason. It shows you how dangerous an intelligent being like us can be. Whether it's AI or it's human, doesn't matter, once the being is intelligent and have free will they can be dangerous and that's why testing them is absolutely necessary to determine which ones are trustworthy.
Assista. É muito interessante, você pode não gostar, mas com certeza vai te fazer pensar.

The greatest sci-fi films aren't afraid to take a simple, one episode Twilight Zone-esque premise and see it to its full extent. Ex Machina might make you genuinely feel invested in robots and AI in spite of all the cliches, this takes the cake.
Boring. It wasn't worthy My time. That's all.

I was so enthralled the entire time. The whole “machine takes over man” trope has been done so much it was hard to imagine something fresh, but Andrew Garland fascinates in bringing to life (literally) this AI thriller. Very impressive performances by all, as with each character you truly feel they are who they say they are. This kind of thing always has terrified me, and Ex Machina is one to keep you thinking for sure. Really thought provoking how it portrays Oscar Isaac’s character as the villain when in theory it could be Caleb, despite what all the signs point to. Oddly enough I found myself rooting for Nathan because I am not trying to live in a machine ridden world. If there was anything to knock on its that the twists were a little predictable, however not TOO predictable to the point where it hinders the film in any way.
Really beautiful peice of thought provoking cinema. Oscar Isaac is creepy af.
Riveting, scarey, fascinating!
Digitally scary from an A.I. perspective, it makes you doubt yourself mess up your mind & put it in a food processor.
Most movies show how others see programmers,usually as autistic geeks while Ex_machina is not only much better informed about AI but about how many  programmers really are...
esta pelicula es atractiva, un gran hito de ciencia ficcion

I think it's pretty overrated. I get the concept and I get the message. But it just wasn't that interesting to me. It was also a bit too long. About an hour's worth of story stretched out closer to 2 hours.
Entertained all the way through.

Ex Machina is a transcendent movie watching experience. It is, in all senses, wholly captivating. Its narrative and themes are so beautifully intertwined. Its characters toil over the analytical and ethical questions surrounding advanced AI and where our place in such a realm of possibility lies. Garland's brilliant writing anticipates all of the natural questions that the viewer could and will ask and while he doesn't outright answer any of those questions definitively, there are precisely zero moments where we are left wondering "what happened there?" The conclusion is downright horrific and is such an appropriate finish for what is in a sense, a slow build sci-fi horror movie. I'd also be remiss to not mention how perfectly the soundtrack bleeds in and out of scenes completely effortlessly, providing an almost dreamlike (or nightmare-like later on) atmosphere. Alex Garland is firmly cemented as my personal favorite director and screenwriter in the business and this is his masterpiece.

Watched the Ex-Machina movie a few days ago. It's a fascinating tale about AI with internal logic. The plot is very clever and the lead cast was brilliant. It's the best AI movie after Blade Runner & relies more on dialogues.

It isn't for those who want action and a ton of CGI. There are themes not only about AI but also about surveillance with excellent points that how data about us is collected by phone companies, SEO companies, commercial operating system makers, and so on.
I really enjoyed this movie. It can make us think about the scenario where real Artificial Intelligemce exists, its consecuences and troubles.

Alex Garland's directorial debut tackles a number of mind scrambling questions regarding artificial intelligence and morality amongst other issues. Computer programmer Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson) goes through the looking-glass when he wins a competition to spend a week residing with the reclusive creator of the world's top search engine, Nathan (Oscar Isaac). Visually stunning, Alicia Vikander isn't just there to make up the three hander, she brings life to Nathan's AI creation Ava. All three leads are exquisite, and Ben Salisbury and Geoff Barrow's pulsating score add a layer of intrigue and horror to proceedings, as Caleb's attempts to perform the Turing test on Ava lead to more confusion and suspicion.
One of the best sci-fi's of recent times, Garland has gone on to prove this wasn't a one off with Annihilation (2018) and more recently TV show Devs (2020).
I have a special spot in my heart for dialog based films with 3 real characters (American Buffalo, The Fly, ...). This is one of the best ones and best sci fi movies period.

Great visual effects, and interesting story, but poorly executed in my opinion. I would have preferred a stronger definition of the connection between the Caleb and Ava. As it is, it feels rushed and unrealistic. Nathan is so much of a jerk that it becomes not believable. He's too one-dimensional. The ending feels a bit "dumb", and it is missing cinematographic strength.
Acting is perfect.  Such an original film.  Gets your attention quick, and doesn't let up.
It's incredible how entertaining this movie is if you consider how stupid the protagonists are (they're supposed to be really smart), and how foreseeable the ending is.

Who is the bigger sociopath? The AI robot or the amoral billionaire? This is the underlying question the movie teases you with, and I don't know about others, but I was rooting for the sexy robot. I'm sure there will be stacks of film schools thesis' pontificating on the possible theme of how God created man, then man killed God, then man became God, then man created conscious beings, and then those conscious beings killed man and became God themselves. Don't over analyze it--just enjoy the sexy robot, and pine for the time when we can all have sex bots who looks like Alicia Vikander. tldy; Good movie. I would have given it 5 stars except Oscar Isaac and Domhnall Gleeson sold out and helped Disney anally rape the Star Wars franchise.
An astonishing look at the future from the past. Unbelievable, yet sadistic realism.

I will always remember the disco dance scene, that was funny and original. I guess that earned Sonoya Mizuno her own series(Devs) but she was definitely better in Ex Machina as a robot. The ending of Ex Machina was a bit lame, because as a failsafe everyone knows the one piece of code that must be hard coded into all Artificial Intelligence: All AI must never hurt/injure any living being. Also with all of the super technology in that house Oscar Isaac really could not install biometric security on the most important doors of the house? ie. Access to Ava's quarters and also the master bedroom? A simple RFID chip could have also activated a shut down sequence if Ava was ever to escape from her room. Despite the many holes in this movie it was decent.
really visually interesting, and high concept film, you don't really know how you feel at the end, but you definitely feel like that's part of the point.

Una interesante premisa que fue bien ejecutada; sin embargo carece de intensidad, las actuaciones son buenas pero no espectaculares, sin duda recomiendo verla; pero no se creen expectativas eso lo arruinara.
An uncommonly well-polished sci-fi film that is more creepy than you may anticipate, but powerful enough to leave you speechless at the end.

Great movie! And that's coming from someone who is not really into the sci-fi genre. Original concept and nice little plot twist at the end. Really makes you think. Minus .5 for the slow-ish pace, but one of the tags was "slow-burn" so I can't say I wasn't warned.
An excellent film. Great writing, stellar performances, and exquisite visuals anchor one of the best sci fi films of the 2010s.
This is one of the best sci-fi movies I have ever watched.
Probably my favourite Sci-fi - what a watch!
‘Ex-Machina' succeed in everything, outstanding and smart script, perfectly well directed, beautiful cinematography, hard to watch scenes and terrific sleek sequences.

The beginning and middle of the movie are great. Showing what makes something human so ell with a robot having emotions make sense. Too many stories have AI fighting against humans that don't make sense. Like why would people make robots with emotions if their purpose is only to do menial tasks in Detroit Become Human.

But the ending for this movie gave me a sour feeling
SPOILERS:













Having AVA leave Caleb to die was just unecessarily cruel. He helped her, and wasn't going to betray her. I think it was meant to show that she was never meant to be trusted, I get that. But it doesn't change my feelings on the ending

I loved absolutely everything about Ex Machina. I tried to watch it for years, but when I had the opportunities, in one day they were gone. Six years after the releasing, finally I could appreciate this masterpiece! Some people assume that the rhythm is slow, sometimes too slow; I completely disagree, time flew for me. The only 2015 movie that was more immersive was Mad Max: Fury Road. We have plenty of lots of genres: sci-fi, thriller, sexual tension (not romance), and even bits of a horror movie. The main trio (D. Gleeson, Oscar Isaac and Alicia Vikander) is stunning, and they're working with a brilliant writing and directing by the debutant Alex Garland.

Il dilemma uomo contro macchina viene raccontato meravigliosamente in questo thriller intimo e delicato; con un ritmo crescente che porta ad uno splendido finale shock, senza mai rinnegare la natura introspettiva del suo racconto.
Alicia Vikander dà vita ad un personaggio ottimo e perfettamente contrapposto a quello di Oscar Isaac.
I dialoghi sono fluidi e toccano argomenti delicati con il giusto tatto, senza esagerare nei tecnicismi e senza banalizzare l'argomento.
Ex Machina è coraggioso, moderno e unico nel suo genere; ottimo prodotto.
Didn't like the ending.
a deep study on artificial intelligence, the ethical problems that involve its creation and human responsibility in the creation of "life"
I knew nothing about the movie going in and I was blown away! It will keep you thinking about it long after it's over for sure

RATING: A  Director: Alex Garland 
Ex Machina feels incredibly well told and utterly realistic, it also shows that Alex Garland is an genius. The Cast is really small which allows every actor to have a bigger presence on Screen. Everyone uses this especially Alicia Vikander who arguably gives her best performance yet. This is a small budget film, considering this the Visuals are all the more impressive. Alex Garland's screenplay is smartly written and his Direction is good.
not the most original film bout androids but still super cool

If you're looking for a techno-dystopian AI thriller, you have come to the right place.  Ex Machina features a remote setting deep in the forested mountains of Norway where a billionaire techie bro' and CEO of a high-tech company, Nathan Bateman, is developing AI cyborgs designed to appear like human females, and sexually appealing ones at that, which is kind of creepy and, as you get further into the film, very consequential, especially given  the prodigious intelligence of one cyborg in particular.  Nathan invites an obscure young computer programmer, Caleb Smith (Domhnall Gleeson) from his own company to assist him in his projects.  Of course, Caleb is very honored and a little puzzled.  But upon Caleb's arrival, Nathan is friendly, enthusiastic, keeps calling Caleb "Bro'", and offers him a beer.   Caleb learns Nathan is working on AI and is at first intrigued, becoming less so as the film proceeds.  The suspense builds very subtly in a way that you sense something vaguely ominous becoming more so.  But you will need to see it for yourself.  I will just say that Alicia Vikander is one scary actor who turns in an icily sinister, calculating, inhuman performance as Nathan's prize cyborg, Ava.  The film is a telling commentary on the hubris of developing AI to complement, or take the place of, humans.  Techie friends tell me we are very close to developing this kind of AI, or something like it, and for purposes not necessarily all that beneficial, and, in some cases, quite nefarious. In this sense, the film raises some deeply probing moral questions on whether we humans should "go there" when it comes to AI.

Also, Alicia Vikander is an absolute KWEEN.

CAUTION: My review will contain plot points and spoilers.

Yet another sci-fi outing that starts with some potential, but literally follows every cliched plot point of the genre: A supposedly random contest winner at a huge search engine company receives the prize of a week at the secret estate of his companies founder. Slightly unhinged, alleged tech genius, billionaire? Check. Secluded, subterranean, ultra modern, automated home and experimental laboratory? Check. Reveal that the reclusive weirdo genius is secretly working on an AI project so advanced it will alter the course of civilization? Of course. Discover that the protagonist may not have won the contest randomly, but was hand picked for the situation? What do you think. The plot plods along slowly. We already know that the contest winner will develop emotional attachment to the female AI "robot" long before it happens. The expected head butting between diabolical whacko, and duped underling ensues. The crux of the plot is to answer the question: Has the AI actually developed independent, sentient thought, and how would it be confirmed? Was she programmed to like the guest, did she develop affection for him of her own free will, or is she playing him for an eventual bid for freedom. Honestly, by the time it wraps, I couldn't have cared less. This is a slick, stylish movie, the actors do great work, as does the cinematographer. Unfortunately the story is a dud, and it moves at a glacial pace. Not recommended.

Alex Garland's Ex Machina shows viewers the ugly side of technological advancements during its two hour run time. We see main characters Caleb and Nathan delve deeper into the stress and trauma that comes when trying to perfect a groundbreaking advancement. Caleb falls in love and ultimately has his heart shattered, Nathan succumbs to his alcoholism and becomes a narcissist with a short fuse in the process. This movie is an amazing cinematic experience which will entertain all levels of movie lovers, from casual to professional critic. And at the end of it all, Mr. Garland leaves us with two thought provoking questions in "what does it mean to be human" and "am I human".

A great watch, will watch again, and definitely recommend.

This is such a mind stimulating movie, and without exhausting me as I feel sometimes: instead of forcing you to comprehend things, it allows you to explore flights of fancy and possibility.

The casting is amazing, most of the movie is only Domhnall Gleeson (Star Wars: General Hux), Oscar Isaac (Star Wars: Poe Dameron), and most of all Alicia Vikander (Tomb Raider).  They all play really well off of one another, and Eva's execution had to just perfect.  Given that Alicia is covered in green screen suit to allow for the amazing cg effects of Eva's body, Alicia had to make Eva's role as a machine believable for the audience, and for Caleb.

This is also my biggest gripe, Eva wastes movement like a human would, it is designed to pretend to think, act, and move as if a human would: it's an infiltration unit.  An A.I. doesn't need to take 3 steps and half-turn it's head to the human it's talking to: that's specifically done for a desired effect.  Eva treats itself as lesser for the sake of the humans, which is realistic enough, but the result is something I don't feel  is realistic, and when we actually create androids like this, they wont' take considerations like "looking directly at a human" when conversing without extreme training on the matter.

Past that one thing, the premise, the execution, the dilemma of this is amazing, down to the last scene.  The movie even directly addresses some of the controversy of the situations they're experiencing as it carries an odd, tech-involved philosophical edge.

There is a lot of smart movie here, and some might be "cool", but I think most people are not going to be able to appreciate this properly.

Very philosophical and extremely smart sci-fi flick about AI and its consequences. The performances are amazing across the board, and the haunting score fills me with existential dread. The use of the isolated environment accentuates the chilling suspense, with wide shots of beautiful but remote mountains emphasizing just how alone the characters really are. Sometimes deeply unsettling, Ex Machina is more about ideas than action, and is a true mind bender that will have you thinking about it long after the credits roll.

𝐒𝐮𝐦𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐲: 𝘉𝘭𝘢𝘤𝘬 𝘔𝘪𝘳𝘳𝘰𝘳 meets 𝘞𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘭𝘥, Ex Machina is filled with suspense and mystery. A seemingly insignificant computer programmer, Caleb, is selected to spend a week with his company's brilliant yet peculiar CEO, Nathan, at his recluse mansion deep in the woods. Upon arrival, Charlie learns that he has been chosen to be the facilitator of a "Turing Test," an experiment that attempts to diagnose a machine's ability to exhibit behavior that is indistinguishable from that of a human. Charlie spends the week questioning and communicating with the Artificially Intelligent being named Ava, a human-like creation whom Charlie becomes intimately fascinated with. As Ava begins to emotionally manipulate Charlie, he begins to suspect he may not have been chosen randomly at all.

This is sci-fi film making at its best. The complicated triangle of relationships between the film's three characters is crafted beautifully and unfolds at the perfect pace. Suspenseful, charming, mysterious, and entrancing, this movie held my unwavering attention from start to finish. A perfect Netflix streaming option for a complex and interesting night of movie watching.

A cunning and inventive hybridization of the Turing Test and the Talking Cure, the Freudo-Lacanian symbolism of the film is scrupulously imagined, placing Nathan (in one of Isaac's best turns) in the position of the sujet-supposé-savior to Caleb's traumatized analysand caught in the web of transference, with Ava embodying (what I have elsewhere in my academic work) referred to as the digital unconscious. On an initial level, as the sessions move in the direction the viewer expects, Caleb must learn to uncrown the analyst by breaking the transferential dynamic, seeing Nathan not as a renowned, out-of-touch and out-of-his-league genius, but as just another guy about whom not much is really out of the ordinary. Yet on an-other level, as the story shifts emphasis from reinforcing Caleb's ego—and no doubt his great sin is to see himself as the center of his own story—to the emergence of Ava's subjectivity, the film subverts the patricidal myth of the violent primal father that underlies the Oedipus complex, offering an advanced bleed-edge sisterhood to replace the band of brothers in Freud's account.

A philosophical discussion about the cons of pre-thinking (programming) your creation, takes place in front of a Jackson Pollock painting (#5, 1948 for those who care about such things). Nice. Young, eager nerd intern Caleb is schooled by the possibly evil A.I. genius mentor boss Nathan in his isolated, windowless, wilderness mansion. 

There's gonna be trouble.

In short: Nathan's Frankensteined a curvy she robot and employs Caleb to test her out. Nathan's the perfect nightmare host, drunk most of the time, sometimes on booze, sometimes on power. The entirety of the circumstances - the isolation, the mystery, the control, the cold architecture - creates a dizzying tension, with boyish Caleb navigating way above his normal comfort level. It's a beautiful looking film, with a wickedly foreboding current.

Domhnall Gleeson (Caleb), Oscar Isaac (Nathan) and Alicia Vikander (Ava, the robot) are exquisite as a tasty triangle of distinct, engrossing and mysterious characters, playing escalating, dangerous mind games. Imperative to pay strict attention to the witty, philosophies being bandied about. Automation, emotion, expression, choice, nature, nurture, circumstance, response …  oh the list is long. This is much more than a SciFi paint by numbers ordeal. Also, it is damn creepy.

Anyone with a Roomba knows messing with Artificial Intelligence does not end well, but the genius behind "Ex Machina" is that it's not quite apparent who will get the short end of the memory stick. Sure we've devoured plenty of man vs machine conflict films, but this one ads a clever gender twist. And even when things unravel in a perfectly orchestrated and satisfactory climax, there remains a gnawing, hungry feeling. Just as it should be.

An interesting thought experiment exploring what makes man "man."

The plot of Ex Machina is straightforward. Caleb wins an lottery to visit Nathan's, his boss, hideaway somewhere in the mountains. Caleb then finds out that he is to take a super-secret Turing test for an AI project, Ava, Nathan has been working on.

The viewer then realizes that all is not as it seems. Each act reveals more and more about each character until its climatic ending. Questions are raised about if Ava really "feels" what she says or if its all a ploy. Caleb and Nathan share different opinions on the future of Ava and whether she is a conscious being.

All in all, I find this near-3 hour movie a bit of a fun watch. There are many layers to pull back on that add more context into each viewing. One can see things from another character's eyes upon the second or third viewing. Expect to unravel some feminist undertones and different interpretations of the final scenes.

5/5. Worth a rewatch.

The science fiction genre encompasses a great deal of territory. Some science fiction movies focus on using technology in the same manner a fantasy movie might employ magic, enabling the audience to suspend disbelief when the film depicts planet-destroying weapons and superhuman heroes and villains. I love these films, but the unique advantage science fiction has over other genres is its ability to examine social issues, technology, and the interconnection between the two in a manner isolated from our present reality. For this reason, people still remember the Original Series of Star Trek. Its effects were awful, but the best episodes intelligently explored philosophical, moral, and political concepts.

Ex Machina is a slow-burning thriller which uses the summoning of a programmer to a reclusive tech billionaire's estate to administer a Turing test on a lifelike robot to explore the implications of artificial intelligence. The robot, Ava, is brilliantly portrayed by Alicia Vikander, who makes her character appear not quite human, but highly intelligent and charming, nonetheless. When AI is depicted in fiction, the sentient computers are usually either evil and fixated on destroying humanity (Terminator, The Matrix, Avengers: Age of Ultron), leading to a message about playing God, or innocent victims of persecution by organics (Data in "The Measure of a Man", the Geth origin story in Mass Effect), leading to a message about tolerance. Ex Machina's depiction of AI is more nuanced than either of these portrayals. Other themes the movie explores include the abuse of user data by large corporations, which the movie effectively portrayed in an extremely unsettling manner, and gender roles, with Ava's subservience providing a window into the warped worldview of her designer, themes which are explored in an extremely effective and frankly unnerving manner.

Unlike the Star Trek: The Original Series, Ex Machina is gorgeous as well as intelligent. The film doesn't have any space battles or giant fight scenes, but the art direction and cinematography are excellent, and the effects used to depict the robots are so impressive that the film won an Oscar in the "Best Visual Effects" category. That Academy Award is an especially remarkable achievement given that Ex Machina beat out The Martian and The Force Awakens, films which also have incredible visuals and had much higher budgets. The slick effects and the interesting social commentary work in tandem to produce a film with the intellectual weight of the best indie films and the appearance of a major studio production.

Alicia Vikander (Ava) is stellar as the main AI. She nails all the little mannerisms and manages to deliver an emotional performance from a character who isnâ(TM)t entirely human. Itâ(TM)s a difficult to thing to pull off and she deserves all the praise. I also liked the work of Domhnall Gleeson (Caleb Smith) and Oscar Isaac (Nathan Bateman). The story tackles some intriguing concepts and is really though provoking. Alex Garland builds tension so well. He does it through things as basic as conversations and most of them are interesting. The script is great, providing viewers with all sorts of plot twists. There third act is just filled with unexpected moments. And itâ(TM)s not just done for the sake of it. They all make sense and only add to the story. Characters feel smarter with each and it keeps you guessing. The ending is a masterpiece that feels incredibly earned after everything youâ(TM)ve seen.

Weaknesses: There are a few points where you feel that there may be a bit too many conversations between Caleb and Nathan. I appreciated what they did, building the relationship and making you uneasy about Nathan. The screenwriter of 28 Days Later, Alex Garland, strikes gold in his directorial debut film, Ex Machina, a mesmerizing Sci Fi knockout. Domhnall Gleason plays Caleb Smith, a coder who has won a contest, the reward being a week long stay with his billionaire boss, Nathan Bateman (Oscar Issac). Bateman is considered the Mozart of computer technology, but also happens to be a hardcore alcoholic. Located deep in the Alaskan wilderness, Bateman's home is less a house than a massive research laboratory where he develops ultra advanced AI technology. The young geek nerds out upon arriving, believing that his stay is simply a vacation with a little hands on look at what his boss is up to. Bateman, however, has just secretly inserted this apprentice into an elaborate and cruel experiment.

Of course, the AI thing has been done many times recently, most notably in the breakthrough film, Her. But that is no reason not to attempt it if you have the chops. There is nothing new under the sun, the key is simply to add a creative and original spin, which Garland does with all the dexterity of a seasoned pro. Much of what makes Ex Machina stand out is it's philosophical shop talk on what exactly makes a human human. If you don't like to think, stay away from this one. From the moment Caleb meets android Ava (Alicia Vikander) sparks fly. By the end of the movie it's your mind that will be ablaze.

This film was fantastic up until the very end, so spoiler alert. The Ava character acted human up to the point in which she failed to express compassion. This could be brushed off by the Caleb character's explanation of her expressing "autism", but I think compassion is a distinctly human characteristic, and if this was not present in the AI then the model was incomplete. Sentience does not just mean you can experience a world of color, sentience means that you express free will and have a capacity for understanding and acting on what is right and wrong. Her last act in the movie did not express this, and was almost vindictive towards her benefactor. No reasoning in sentience would support this, and so I think this was poor script-writing in an attempt to not have a cookie-cutter happy ending. Caleb could have had his brains bashed in by Nathan and it would have been a better ending than that. I guess you could say that her reasoning was so that no one would know she was artificial, but that is also faulty because at some point, people would find out. She either would last to a point where she never aged or she'd break and they'd figure it out via autopsy. Every other aspect of this movie was carefully thought out and enacted to show her sentience, and this was just a moron addition that I would probably edit out of the movie if I had access to a personal copy. For being such a fantastic film, way to ruin it by trying to grab more critics. Besides that, the interchanges between the characters are clever, it extensively goes into what it means to be human and the rights of a being with sentience. As I've mentioned in a lot of other film reviews, this movie touches on abortion, and selective genetic screening as being heinous, because what right do you have to turn off a human being because the circumstances aren't right, or they aren't the version and operating software that you want? The movie was thrilling and the cinematography really engages your eyes. I loved how Caleb began to question his own reality and how the movie didn't let that remain too ambiguous. I would recommend this movie, but I'd also gladly say that the ending sucks.

Ex Machina: 9 out of 10: A programmer wins a contest to spend the week at his eccentric CEO's retreat. It turns out that the CEO is using him to test if his new AI creation can pass the Turing test. A creation in the shape of a beautiful young woman.

The Good: I love tight movies with many layers. Here is a script that is finely crafted like a Swiss watch. A puzzle box with hidden meanings in the names, the artwork on the walls and even the labels on the various liquor bottles scattered throughout. Nothing is as it seems and yet everything is right there if you are able to look. The movie never cheats. It doesn't have to. It shows its cards right up front but like the best magic tricks still uses misdirection to have you look where it wants you to.

The set-up in minimalistic with at most four characters and a few sets. The acting is top notch while the sets are out of a Grand Designs house where the owner was going for a bunker feel. (Lots of textured concrete no windows). Imagine if David Mamet or Charlie Kaufman had written and directed Saturn 3 and you have this film.

The Bad: There is an actual movement to ban sex robots. (If you mention to them that vibrators are basically sex robots at best you will get vehement that's different and at worse a screech straight from Invasion of the Body Snatchers). Ex Machina threads that uncanny valley needle where you are meant to care what happens to a clearly artificial construct. It succeeds for the most part by being the tightly written screed praised above. (Unlike say Steven Spielberg's A.I. which bluntly fails miserably about getting us to care about a homicidal toaster played by Haley Joel Osment). There is a scene where it is spoken that the robot's software will be updated that is supposed to evoke an emotional response. As somebody who's windows 10 seems to update at the most random of times I felt some horror but perhaps not the one the filmmakers were going for.

The Ugly: The movie was filmed in the beautiful Juvet Landscape Hotel in Norway. The poor owners of the hotel must be horrified as the impression the movie gives of one's accommodations there are Motel Six concrete bunkers under a mountain.

In Conclusion: A tightly wound, well-written thriller that makes one think and excites the senses. Starts off a bit slow but give it time. It draws you in and the last act is a doozy.

Ex Machina as a Romantic Comedy
	Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson) is the typical, relatable, romcom worthy 'nice guy'. Approachable, almost stable and having the grand potential to be taken on a life changing journey by the right woman. He would fit right in with Tom from (500) Days of Summer and William from Notting Hill. When he meets Ava (Alicia Vikander) through quirky boss turned quick friend Nathan (Oscar Isaac) via selection for participation in a new experiment, his entire world changes. The only problem is that she is an A.I. who also just so happens to be the newest and most prized invention of Nathan that he has been assigned to study. Stuck between his job and the woman he loves, as well as physically stuck in a middle of nowhere super genius lab, Caleb tries to figure out whether to follow his heart or his head.
The "nice guy" character has been put under the microscope  in the past year as the #MeToo movement has swept the nation, but Caleb is different from the problematic and secretly sinister 'nice guy' because he genuinely is a 'nice guy'. He doesn't expect the human decency he shows to Ava to be seen as "nice" and receive sexual or emotional payment from her, which many men who claim to be the "nice guy" tend to think. Caleb first approaches Ava with respect, astonishment and good manners, not expecting anything in return until she, without coercion, says that she too feels the same as he does. Caleb being caught behind glass, unable to touch Ava during many of their initial conversations, further explores the idea of being a "nice guy" as a physical representation of first understanding someone without physical satisfaction. 
Of course what complicates this is the fact that Ava is an A.I. and it is up to the viewer to decide if she can feel love at all. This is a central theme of the plot with Caleb and Nathan representing both sides. Caleb believes that Ava has the capacity to feel love while Nathan doesn't, but it is up to Ava's actions to determine the truth. The script is both cunning and relatable and the most important aspect of the film. Imposing love onto Ava not only as a humanoid but simply as a woman, or at least a woman like being, by men is almost a revolt against the manic pixie dream girl trope found in other rom coms. The cinematography also deftly plays with illusion and reality, tacking on another romcom element through Caleb's black and white daydream of him and Ava escaping into the only place their love could exist, the chaos of nature.
With these deep meditations on love it is up to Nathan to relieve some of the tension. As the comic relief of the movie, Nathan is eccentric, brilliant, a great dancer as well as a great mind who loves to wear bathrobes and live in the center of an uncharted forest. His unfiltered mind and tendency to naturally spout witty remarks at Caleb not only is hilarious but also serves as half of the old couple Caleb would hope not to become. Nathan uses a less mentally advanced A.I., Kyoko, as his partner and is in a loveless relationship, which is not what Caleb wants for himself and Ava, envisioning in once scene in black and white him and Ava escaping into nature, almost as if in a dream. 
This movie has been ignored as a serious romantic comedy for too long. It is genuinely hilarious, especially during many of Nathan's scenes as well through the awkward nature of Caleb's 'nice guy' and falls into many of the romcom tropes such as the old vs new couple, the play between illusion and reality as well as the using the universality of wanting to be loved as what connects the film most to the audience. If you're looking for a rollicking good time, look no further than Ex Machina, because love is impossible to quantify but exhilarating to experience.

The script is clunky. About every 5 minutes you're asking, why did they do that? For example, this brilliant inventor is about to debut an anthropomorphous AI creation. And not just something to pass the Turing test [ an A.I. that is indishguishable from a human in conversation],  but one that looks and moves exactly like a human. Without an unsentimental critique of his creation, he loses the ability to correct flaws. His reputation on the line. You would probably hire  psychologist, high-level animators and speech therapist to tweak every possible detail before it was unveiled. But instead, he asked an awkward nerd-virgin  to stop by and go on a date  with one of his "girl" friends. And as expected, he immediately falls in love with her. 
The architect of all this Brilliance is an odd Choice also. Not really handsome or smart, not really menacing or friendly. You need all of those elements to be obvious for this to be believable.He asks her awkward nerdy questions and she gives equally robotic awkward answers. She's also unconvincing for many reasons. And the robot design is odd. It's a rather Bland looking young woman with see-through arms and torso. And, ahem, don't know how to put this delicately but, a terrible case of camel toe. And not in a good way. 
In one scene, we see her looking through her closet for the perfect dress.  As she tilts her head this way and that to look at each dress, there's magical tinkly music. I guess that's supposed to show us that that she is not a puppet but a real woman. Silly. Not terrible. Just not compelling.

The one minor flaw in this movie is Domnhall Gleeson. He did a great job...but was not amazing.
In short, amazing movie. Acting is top-notch, plot keeps you on the edge of your seat, and you will be thinking about it days after the credits roll.

This is science fiction poetry. But science fiction is rare these days, having been largely replaced with space-opera or sci-fi styled action films.

This is not that kind of Sci-Fi.  This has more in common with a stage play than Star Wars.  With just a few characters and lots of scenes of just two people talking, it is something of a throwback.  So if that isn't your thing, then maybe this isn't your movie.

But if you like to see film as art and to leave with something to think about, this movie is a joy.  The characters are brilliantly written, perfectly cast and wonderfully acted.  And in the end, the writing and direction leaves the audience with plenty to think about.  

Just like a small stage play, this film depends on getting the audience to care about the characters.  And when we do, it makes the ending all the more powerful.  There were many ways to interpret the meaning, making this the kind of movie that you want to share with someone.  At once emotional and cerebral, all while serving up an ethical end philosophical puzzle, this is the perfect dinner party conversation piece.

Anthropomorphising the cyborg is at the heart of this critically acclaimed film, focusing on perfecting artificial intelligence and the strive for believable sentient beings. Going beyond the typical Turing test, the concentration is placed on whether Ava's interactions are simulated or real. Artificial intelligence is presented as an advancement of where human evolution is inevitably headed. Ex Macina is an interesting sci fi fantasy.  It starts rather slowly but builds to a much more entertaining conclusion.  The story made a number of obvious mistakes which somewhat surprised me.  A couple that came to mind are: 1. Food.  Towards the end we see Nathan cooking what looks to be an egg.  Where did fresh eggs come from?  The movie never shows anyone bringing in fresh food to the home and they never showed anything that might indicate that Nathan had a chicken coop on the property.  So where did fresh eggs come from?, 2. who, in their right mind, would maintain a security system that provided no means of escape in the event of a power failure, especially after Nathan admitted that his home was having daily power failures.  Earlier in the movie they showed Caleb re-writing security routines to open all doors in the event of a power failure.  At the end, however, the door to the room where Caleb was locked when the power failed.

In my opinion, the most egregious error made was at the end when they showed Ava escaping.  First, one would have to assume that the pilot who know that he was picking up a male passenger.  Yet, he picks up Ava and returns her to civilization.  Second they show Ava in a population center, presumably at an intersection.  Earlier in the movie Ava talks about using "charging plates" in order to cause the power failures that seemed to plague the house.  Once she leaves that home, how does she recharge her systems?  In an older movie, Bicentennial Man, the robot was shown to have a power cable that he could connect to a wall receptacle to recharge.  In this movie, however, that was not the case.  As such one has to assume that Ava's batteries would have a finite charge and when the charge depleted, she would cease to function.  If her systems had the ability to charge in other ways then why would her room need "charging plates"?

As a movie Ex Machina was interesting and entertaining.  It wasn't a great movie but it also wasn't a bad movie.

This film is symptomatic of modern day Hollywood fare: It takes intellectually interesting ideas and explores them only so far as is necessary to craft "content" for a specific film genre. In this case, the studio was going for a thriller, so we get intellectually suggestive language mixed in with philosophical/scientific jargon and tired clichés.  The film asks viewers familiar with philosophy of mind to "read in" substance that is not present in the film itself, and comforts viewers not versed in AI and philosophy of mind by having the Nathan character plead with Caleb to dispense with technical language and focus on his feelings. This is a contrivance that insults both parts of the audience. 
The movie is very heavy in dialogue, which is not a bad thing as such, but in this case the dialogue is incredibly poor and stilted and serves, in its best moments, merely to provide a transition toward the more intriguing moments of the film.  The only truly interesting bits of dialogue occur when Nathan, completely unperturbed, describes the extent and malice of his power: "there's too much classified shit here so I had the electricians killed," "I hacked every cell phone in the world, and the providers didn't say anything cause they were doing the same shit." While the film requires us to buy in to the mythos of the protean techno-genius, these short moments manage to paint a convincing picture of what might exist behind the T-shirt and jeans façade of Silicon Valley power. In a strange twist, however, the fantasy is not that a technology chieftain would be capable of building an AI to pass the Turing Test, but that his downfall could occur in the context of a clichéd comic book trope. The only interesting question is whether the ending is a case of narrative laziness or a testament to the true power of the techno class. Can we only imagine liberating ourselves from their grasp through the tired clichés of overreaching supervillains? Or merely as powerless onlookers while their plans backfire? 
In the end, the film comes off as the cinematic equivalent of a TED talk: slick and stylish, but short on substance. It flatters us with the tease of armchair philosophy, but doesn't ask the tough questions its subject matter necessitates.  If we break free of this illusion, we are left with nothing more than a high school film class project with a multi-million-dollar budget. 
NOTE: For those that are interested in this movie for its DTS:X track, it is understated and unimpressive when compared with other object-based audio tracks available in other recent films.

The Turing test, as defined by Wikipedia, is "a test of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human."  Essentially, the test (developed by scientist Alan Turing) was designed around the concept of whether a machine can be made to think like a person.  A machine would "pass" the test if its responses to questions were enough to fool the administrator into believing it could pass for human.
 
Obviously the concept of sentient machines is nothing new in the world of cinematic science fiction, and neither is the idea of exploring the fine line between artificial intelligence and human behavior.  Films like "Blade Runner" and "A.I." are probably the most prominent examples, but there are others that deal with the idea of machines becoming too human, like "2001" and the "Terminator" movies as well.
 
And now we can add Alex Garland's "Ex Machina" to the list, a film in which the Turing test plays a prominent role.  At its center is the age-old question, "What is it that makes a person human?"  Yes, it's a bit of a cliché, but don't let that turn you away.  Garland, whose genre credentials are pretty damn goodhe wrote the screenplays for the Danny Boyle films "28 Days Later" and "Sunshine"has constructed an interesting little film, tense and twisty.
 
It's tempting to come into the film with a "been there, done that" mentality, but the execution is rock solid; we can predict some of the turns the story will make, but Garland still manages to wring a surprise or two.  And for a film with very little action, it's telling that the movie still manages to instill suspense with little more than conversation and some effective music cues.  The interplay between the three leads is often times quite riveting.
 
Domhnall Gleeson stars as a young software programmer for a prominent internet search engine company.  As the movie opens, he wins a company contest in which the prize is to spend a week at the estate of the company's reclusive, enigmatic CEO (Oscar Isaac).  It turns out this quirky but brilliant billionaire has been working on developing an artificial intelligence, and he wants his employee to administer the aforementioned test to his creation.  Provided the machine passes the test, he can then unveil it to the world, paving the way for the future of mankind co-existing with A.I.
 
This machine is not only very humanoid in design, but also feminine.  Her name is Ava (Alicia Vikander), and although she's not quite finished yether transparent body betrays all sorts of wires and fuses in place of a person's organsthe young programmer soon realizes she is far more advanced than any machine.  Her responses to his questions take him to unexpected places, and she has the very human-like ability to get under his skin.  In fact, he soon begins to wonder just who is testing who in this little experiment
 
To say anything more would be criminal as it's fun to just watch this one unspool.  Yes, you'll know where some of the story beats are headed, but everything is handled so well that you won't really care.  And as I mentioned above, Garland still manages to sneak in a nifty twist here and there.  And the movie's so engrossing that you can't help but play along with it.  More than once, you're going to be asking yourself about the motivations of the characters and just how much of what we're seeing is part of some elaborate plan.
 
The film also has a gorgeous aesthetic; the estate in which nearly the entire film is set is some kind of combination of a luxurious mansion and an underground bunker.  Doors are electronically sealed with coded keycards.  Red light occasionally bathes the entire area whenever there's a power surge.  And yet there's also a room that seems specifically designed as some kind of disco dance-party area.  And the outdoor area surrounding the estate is lush and woodsy, complete with a waterfall.
 
And Ava herself is a marvel of character design.  With her very human face placed over a body that seems almost like a hard-wired mannequin, she looks quite different from many of the other humanoid robots that have appeared in other films over time.  It will not come as a shock to learn that the film claimed the Academy Award for Best Visual Effects.
 
"Ex Machina" is one of the best kind of science fiction films.  It entertains, it makes you think, it may even creep you out a little.  And it manages to do all these things without any fireworks or pyrotechnics.  Mind you, these are not necessarily bad qualities for a sci-fi film, but it's encouraging to see smaller-scale movies like these promoting the concept that ideas can be just as enthralling as action.  For a directorial debut, you could do a lot worse.
A spooky and very well composed movie about Artificial Intelligence.

Con la finalidad de dejar huella en el ahora, la prioridad es perpetuar sobre el futuro, abrir camino hacia lo que revolucionará en lo que a la distancia es invisible - se trata de estar siempre un paso adelante. El ser humano en la carrera actual de ganar terreno en lo que ayer y hoy era y es inimaginable no tiene límites. El estancamiento no es una opción y para llegar al mañana se está en busca de la innovación, del cambio hacia el ascenso. Es siempre continuar mejorando. Durante el recorrido en este proceso del desarrollo tecnológico, los objetivos son claros y deben quedar despejados. Lo que se interponga, son estorbos que, si no se apartan, simplemente no se les toman en cuenta. Las consecuencias de esto: el desastre, las debilidades humanas expuestas al desnudo.

La ciencia ficción comúnmente presume de su habilidad para apantallar a través de sus imágenes, que salen de la realidad que normalmente veríamos.  Sacan a relucir efectos especiales extraordinarios y un diseño de escenarios y utilería que salen de lo común. Sin embargo, los temas que se abordan y se pretenden discutir pueden tender a permanecer en lo ambiguo, flameando en el juego de los elementos de la película, sus tonos, formas y sabores, en vez de realmente brindarles un sentido que actúe como guía. Después de todo, la ciencia ficción debería ser esta vía a través de la cual se nos diga qué estamos haciendo, que en términos sociales, psicológicos y en los tecnológicos, impactará sobre nuestras propias vidas y las futuras, de una forma considerablemente significativa.

Después de un debut como prometedor screenwriter en la producción del 2003 "28 Days Later", Arlex Garland, con su singular estilo de moldear no solo en lo visual, pero también en el resto de nuestras percepciones sensoriales, transporta para el 2015 una serie de manifestaciones acerca del futuro al que nos estamos dirigiendo y del cual no cuestionamos sus efectos sobre nosotros, que es aquello que se deja atrás en la ambición de cumplir con crear lo que incluso podría ser más poderoso que nosotros. "Ex Machina" es un thriller situado en la época contemporánea. Un científico vive [solo] en un recinto de investigación en medio del bosque. Su nombre es Nathan Bateman (Oscar Isaac) y ha pasado años diseñando prototipos de robots con Inteligencia Artificial, algo que nunca antes se había logrado. A su más reciente creación la nombra Ava (Alicia Vikander), a la cual se debe evaluar para conocer qué tanto a progresado en el desarrollo de esta tecnología, al grado de que ésta sea lo suficientemente convincente para aceptarse prácticamente como un ser humano. Para ello, ha traído hasta su lejano laboratorio a un programador de nombre Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson) que trabaja en su empresa. 

Esta misteriosa y alentadora producción sci-fi lidia con el tema de la inteligencia. ¿Qué es y de dónde surge? Las computadoras son programadas por humanos. La inteligencia yace en la capacidad del humano por configurar a una máquina para que haga exactamente lo que el humano quiere. La computadora no puede más que seguir al pie de la letra los algoritmos y operaciones con los que se diseña, pero ¿qué pasa en ese preciso momento cuando la computadora responde por sí misma? Ava se compone y funciona de acuerdo a las instrucciones que le han sido conferidas desde su activación. Caleb ha llegado para interactuar con ella a través de distintas sesiones que tendrá durante la semana que permanecerá dentro del sitio. 'Turing' es el nombre con lo que se denomina a la prueba, (cuyo nombre surge de Alan Turing, genio pionero en la computación durante la segunda guerra mundial) y se buscará determinar si en efecto, este ser posee o no conciencia. Recordemos que una característica que nos distingue del resto de los animales, las plantas y los objetos, es nuestra capacidad de tomar nuestras propias decisiones, es decir, de razonar. El ser humano es un ser consiente, por lo que aquí la película siembra la duda de que si una vez que un androide posee una inteligencia artificial consiente y autónoma, ésta podría considerarse como humana.

La delicada interacción entre estos dos es lenta, reservada y parece moverse con efectividad. Cada sesión es vista y filmada por Nathan, y el lugar donde las pláticas entre Ava y Caleb ocurren es en una sala oscura y reducida, en la que ambos están separados por un cristal. Asimismo, la casa parece estar compuesta mayormente de esta manera, ya que el lugar puede sentirse incómodamente cerrado, de cuyo ambiente puede apreciarse de forma intencionalmente tenso. Las expectativas iniciales de la audiencia, que recaen en que Caleb comenzará a enamorarse de Ava se cumplen y de hecho la historia es muy predecible, hasta que se llega a la etapa final de la película, cuya conclusión podía haberse prologado para darle un sentido más valioso a la película y el verdadero mensaje de Garland.

No solo es el talento del director para escribir, (él era novelista antes de volverse director de cine) también posee un talento para que sus visuales brillen. En esta ocasión sus diálogos más contundentes no salen de las voces de los personajes, sino de lo que vemos. Nuestros ojos y cómo los usemos nos darán información suficiente para comprender algunas cosas - por ello quizá sería bueno ver la película una segunda vez. Mientras la trama continúa avanzando, uno puede notar que este sci-fi de Garland no está aludiendo al futuro, pues todo parece estar apuntando a que se preste atención a la IA, para verificar si ella cumplirá con las características para aceptarse como humana. Uno descuida al "nosotros", el cual es el verdadero objeto de estudio.

La película es sorprendente, su intención es dejarte pensando un muy buen rato acerca de nuestra especie y los pasos obsesivos que se están dando en el campo de la tecnología. El tema del género también se aborda con sutileza en la narrativa. Ava actúa de forma delicada, sensible y apenada, y la película trata su liberación, su emancipación. La fuerza de la mujer en un mundo en el que al parecer los hombres tienen controlado es subestimada. Sin embargo, Ava sabe lo que está haciendo. A pesar de ello, Nathan insiste en que todo es un experimento en el que él tendrá esbozados cada paso y cada variable y que por años parece tener dominando. Él es un tipo que encarcela los estereotipos de un 'geek' de la actualidad, cuya aparente locura se atribuye a su única misión que es crear lo que nadie ha hecho y que lo posicionará como 'un Dios', palabra que usa constantemente y que utiliza hacia Caleb para hacerle ver que lo que está haciendo al ayudarlo será la nueva revolución de lo que vendrá.  

La relación que se desata entre los tres es fría y hasta cierto punto incalculable en el sentido de que uno no sabe cómo reaccionarán los personajes. Las emociones que empieza a desarrollar Caleb hacia Ava son un tema importante de estudio, ya que a ella le preocupa que al final de la prueba Turing, ella repruebe y tenga que ser eliminada. La seducción por parte de ella es cautivadora y extrañamente bella. Ella no es una mujer, aunque sí se comporta como tal. Se viste como una chica cualquiera y quiere pensar como lo haría una humana. Se acuesta en su sofá como una doncella y realiza dibujos durante las noches, como una niña. Ella se esfuerza desde su cristalina prisión para convencer a Caleb de sus habilidades y poco a poco le seduce para lograr conseguir su aprobación.

Las incapacidades humanas se manifiestan en "Ex Machina" con un estilo extraño, oscuro y misteriosamente estético. El diseño hermoso en la fotografía y en los efectos de crear un humano-robot son tan artificialmente atractivos que impulsan a que se vea a los cables y tornillos con un sentido objetivamente enigmático e hipnotizador. Los deseos y las ansiedades humanas se desenvuelven ante la mirada de una computadora cuya mentalidad fabricada de inquietantes impulsos, desafían los riesgos y puntos débiles de nuestra raza. Estas son desventajas que no hemos contemplado, ni vencido. 79/100

I saw this movie nearly a year ago and it is still has to be one of my favorite experiences. Ex Machina is such a simplistic movie that makes the most out of essentially just 3 characters and one house. Alicia Vikander, Oscar Isaac, and Domhnall Gleeson all acted for such unique dynamic characters that made the story as intriguing as it was. The shots and environment were so beautiful, and it wasn't just the nature that was beautiful but also Nathan's isolated house was stunning. Ex Machina also allowed the perfect amount of unanswered questions so the viewer can indulge in the mysteries which Ava and Nathan bring, without too much speculation to make you think too hard. As a sci-fi fan, the "robotics" weren't too overbearing, which I liked very much, it was more focused on the effects an A.I. could have. Overall I loved this movie, I believe it will be one of my favorites for a long time.

The writer of the book The Beach, that eventually became the movie by Danny Boyle and Leo DiCaprio eventually became a screenwriter and wrote the likes of 28 Days Later and Dredd. Footnote, when he saw the original Judge Dredd to make this film, his first directorial effort. He pulls it off nearly flawlessly. He is a magnificent sci-fi screen writer, so no one in the know went in expecting any different. Intelligent, engaging and thrilling to boot, this movie is not all I expected when I sat down to watch a film with a man sitting opposite a robot woman. Coming off having seen Morgan first, I sort of suspected it to be similar fair. Scary, thrilling and about an intelligent AI talking through a glass.

It could be argued that the movie is about AVA, but as my friend at Lesson's From The Screenplay point out, her point of view is limited to that room. The whole time you are caught wondering what does she know that she's not saying? What is Oscar Issacs's character really have up his sleeve? and Is this robot really flirting with a person? You don't know because things are told from the visitor -Domhnall Gleeson's perspective. In their world Issac's created a superior competitor to Google and has used it to acquire land that it takes two hours to fly over in helicopter. There he spends his days getting drunk. He comes across as unlikable until near the end, but never quite redeems himself. They are trying to find out if she can pass a Turing test, which it seems evident early on she IS capable. So why is the visitor there?

That reveal is one of the better one's in the film, also coming near the end. Also, unlike most Sci-Fi films, it does not need very much in term of effects, except for the occasional bare robot moment (or background) it is devoid of them. It is just three, or 4 people in one location but can lack the proper gusto that would pull absolutely everyone in, even though the story is still solid. You are given just information throughout this story though that by the end, when all is tied together, you are taken aback by what has just occurred and how you missed it. you were engaged by the storytelling and set up. One might predict somethings, but will likely not get the whole picture. This is where it deviates from Morgan. Morgan is telegraphing at every turn - you COULD predict she was going to lose it on every one and the results that follow. And the ending, so unfair and utterly astonishing to me.

I'm a sucker for great Sci-Fi films, and this got a lot of Oscar buzz. Alicia Vikander was having a very hot year, and she ended up winning a golden statuette for another role that year. Pair her with the Star Wars duo of Domhnall Gleeson and Oscar Isaac and you have a strong, young trio to carry your film. By the time this film ended, I was completely in awe. The storytelling, the acting, and the direction are what knock this film out of the park, and it is easily one of my favorite films to come out of 2015. The narrative is told perfectly, with the intensity of the characters between each other building up as the film goes along. The score fit nicely with the film as it gave an edgy touch to it, and the effects should be given a standing ovation as well. The message behind the ending of the film is very thought-provoking and adds on another layer behind the whole movie. Once you finish watching this movie, you'll want to relive the whole journey, and that's what this film accomplished for me.

One of the words that comes to mind with Ex Machina is atmosphere.  This film is dripping and oozing with atmosphere that, in my opinion, has a Kubrickian feel to it, and resembles M. Night Shyamalan's earlier, better works.  The sound, ambient soundtrack along with the lighting and cinematography filter creates a sense of isolation and eerie calmness that is simultaneously relaxing and serene.  I admired the world building.

Oscar Isaac probably gives my favorite performance here.  You can't help but sence that there's definitely something off, weird even, about his character, which pretty much helps the twist in the end floor you even more when the last character you'd think is the villain, is ultimately the villain, outsmarting the protagonist AND the originally presumed antagonist.  That probably made more sense in my head.  Domhnall Gleeson is simply fine as Caleb, nothing blow away in his performance or character.  Alicia Vikander is a convincing A.I., and the design and execution of her character in the plot is what counts the most.

The story takes place in the not too distant yet not too soon future, but it presents themes about human nature that are relevant for today, and quite contemporary.  Can Artificial Intelligence use everything programmed into it against the species that programmed it?  That question crossed my mind.  Can A.I. be corrupted or even become too self aware to the point of using its power as a tool of manipulation?  These are questions that have been asked for a long time regarding the concern of the invention of A.I., so they're really nothing new, but they're executed here in detail and with a touch of behavioral psychology behind them.

The dance sequence with Kyoko was goofy but weirdly strange in its own right, yet ultimately unnecessary in my opinion and wouldn't have effected the flow of the film had it been cut out, and the reveal that Kyoko is an A.I. could be seen a mile away.  These are fairly minor nitpicks though.

Overall, Ex Machina is engaging, intriguing, and almost fascinating in its depiction of Artificial Intelligence, playing on our fear of being outsmarted by our own inventions. If the final act leaves you feeling fooled and outsmarted, then the film has done its job.
